case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Mysore Chromite Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 117 of 1953 is an appeal from the Judgment and Order dated 29th March 1951 of the High Court of Judicature at Madras in Case Referred No. 44 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil AppealNo. 117 of 1953. Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 29th day of March, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Madras in Case Referred No. 44 of 1948.

facts.text: The respondent is Mysore Chromite Ltd., a private limited company registered in Mysore State with registered office at Sinduvalli.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee companypany is a private limited companypany registered in the Mysore State under the Mysore Company Regulations and has its registered office at Sinduvalli in Mysore State.

facts.text: Management and control of the assessee company was vested in Messrs. Oakley Bowden & Co. Madras Ltd., registered office at No. 15, Armenian Street, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The management and companytrol of the assessee companypany was vested in Messrs. Oakley Bowden Co.  Madras  Ltd., another private limited companypany incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, having its registered office at No. 15, Armenian Street, Madras.

facts.text: The assessee company owns chromite mines in Mysore State and extracts chrome ores, converts them into merchantable product, sold mostly to buyers outside India.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee companypany owns chromite mines in Mysore State. Chrome ores are extracted from the mines and companyverted into a merchantable product and then sold to buyers mostly outside India.

facts.text: Sales to European buyers are put through in London by Bowden Oakley Co. Ltd., London, agent of assessee holding power of attorney; contracts signed in London.

anchor.surface_text: The sales to the purchasers in Europe are put through in London by Bowden Oakley Co. Ltd., London, which is the agent of the assessee companypany in Europe holding a power of attorney from the assessee companypany.

facts.text: Sales to American buyers effected through W.R. Grace & Co., who buy for undisclosed principals; contracts signed by W.R. Grace & Co. presumably in America and by Oakley Bowden & Co. Madras Ltd. in Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The sales to purchasers in America are effected through Messrs. W. R. Grace Co., who buy for undisclosed principals. The companytracts for sale to American purchasers are signed by W. R. Grace Co., presumably in America and by Oakley Bowden Co.  Madras , Ltd., in Madras.

facts.text: Contracts specify price F.C.B. Madras or Marmagoa; provision for weighment, sampling and assay at destination.

anchor.surface_text: Under both forms of companytracts the price was F.C.B. Madras or Marmagoa. A very small quantity of goods was sold F.O.B. Marmagoa and the same need number be companysidered here. Provision was made for weighment, sampling and assay of goods at destination.

facts.text: European contract payment: Buyers open confirmed irrevocable Bankers credit for 90% of invoice against documents, balance in London after final invoice.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of payment under the European companytract were as follows- Payment.-Buyers to open a companyfirmed irrevocable Bankers credit in favour of Messrs. Mysore Chromite Ltd., Madras  to be advised to sellers  through the Eastern Bank Ltd., for 90 per cent.  ninety per cent  of the Provincial  sic  Invoice against documents.

facts.text: American contract payment: Letter of credit for 80% at 90 days sight, balance by telegraphic transfer through London after assay.

anchor.surface_text: The companyresponding terms of payment under the American companytracts were as follows- Payment.-Letter of credit for eighty per cent.  80 per cent.  of invoice value to be available against drafts at ninety  90  days sight with documents attached to be opened immediately in London in favour of the seller.

facts.text: Before shipment, buyers open confirmed irrevocable credit with bank in London; Eastern Bank London intimates Madras, who informs assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrse of dealing as found by the Appellate Tribunal was as follows. Before the goods were actually shipped, the buyers used to open a companyfirmed irrevocable Bankers credit with some first class bank in London.

facts.text: Assessee ships goods at Madras, obtains bill of lading in own name.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of such intimation the assessee companypany placed the companytracted goods on board the steamer at Madras and obtained A bill of lading in its own name.

facts.text: Assessee draws bill of exchange on buyers' bank for 90% (Europe) or 80% (America) of provisional invoice, negotiates with Eastern Bank Madras, who credits assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the assessee companypany used to make out a provisional invoice on the basis of the bill of lading weight and companytract price for 48 per cent. Cr. 203 and used to draw a bill of exchange on the buyers Bank, where the letter of credit had been opened, for 90 per cent.

facts.text: Eastern Bank Madras forwards documents to London branch, who presents to buyers' bank; upon acceptance, delivers BL and invoice.

anchor.surface_text: The bill of exchange together with the relative bill of lading endorsed in blank by the assessee companypany and the provisional invoice was then negotiated with the Eastern Bank Ltd., Madras, the bankers of the assessee companypany, Who used to credit the assessee companypany with the amount of the bill of exchange.

facts.text: Buyers' bank pays Eastern Bank London; balance after weighment/assay paid to Eastern Bank London, assessee's agent.

anchor.surface_text: The buyers Bank in due companyrse used to pay the amount of the bill of exchange to the Eastern Bank Ltd., London. Thereafter, on arrival of the goods and after weighment and assay, the sale price was ascertained and the balance of price, after deducting the payments made against the bill of exchange, used to be paid to the Eastern Bank Ltd., London,

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed assessee on entire profits from these sales as arising and received in British India.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts stated above the Income-tax Officer assessed the assessee companypany on the entire profits in respect of these sales on the footing that they arose and were also received in British India.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the assessment.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner companyfirmed the assessment.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal by order dated 22nd January 1948 held sales took place outside British India and money received by agent in London.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee companypany went up on appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal. The Tribunal by its order dated the 22nd January,1948, came to the companyclusion that the sales took place outside British India and that the money in respect of such sales was also received by the agent of the. assessee companypany in London.

facts.text: Commissioner applied to Tribunal to refer questions under section 66; Tribunal referred two questions.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax thereupon applied to the Appellate Tribunal requiring the latter to state a case and refer certain questions of law said to rise out of the order of the Tribunal. The Appellate Tribunal accordingly referred the two questions of law hereinbefore set out.

facts.text: High Court of Madras answered both questions in affirmative, upholding Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Madras in a well reasoned judgment upheld the decision of the Appellate Tribunal and answered the two questions in the affirmative and against the Commissioner of Income-tax.

facts.text: Commissioner preferred appeal to Supreme Court with certificate of fitness.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax has number preferred this appeal with a certificate of fitness from the High Court.

facts.text: Proceedings for assessment years 1939-1940, 1940-1941, 1941-1942, 1942-1943.

anchor.surface_text: The above Questions of law arose out of proceedings for the assessment to income-tax of the respondent, Mysore Chromite Ltd.  hereinafter referred to as the asseessee companypany , for the years 1939-1940, 1940 1941, 1941-1942 and 1942-1943.

facts.text: It was agreed between department and assessee that income arose at the place where sales took place.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the statement of case as also from the order of the Appellate Tribunal that it was agreed between the department and the assessee companypany that the income arose at the place, wherever that be, where, the sales took place.

facts.text: Contracts were for sale of unascertained goods.

anchor.surface_text: In 857, the present case, the companytracts were always for sale of unascertained, goods.

facts.text: Property in goods did not pass until bill of exchange accepted by buyers' bank in London and documents delivered there.

anchor.surface_text: Suffice it to say, for the purposes of this case, that in any event upon the terms of the companytracts in question and the companyrse of dealings between the parties the property in the goods companyld number have passed to the buyer earlier than the date when the bill of exchange was accepted by the buyers Bank in London and the documents were delivered by the assessee companypanys agent,

facts.text: Eastern Bank Ltd., Madras and London were agents of the assessee company.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the fact found is that the Eastern Bank Ltd., Madras, and the Eastern Bank Ltd., London., were agents of the assessee companypany. Neither of them had any relation with the buyers.
under section 66 1  of the Income-tax Act whereby the High Court answered. in the affirmative both the referred questions which were expressed in the following terms

concepts.interpretation: Agreed that profits from sales arise at the place where the sales take place.

anchor.surface_text: According to section 4 of the Indian Sale of Goods Act a compantract of sale of goods is a compantract whereby the seller transfer, or agrees to transfer the property in goods to the buyer for a price and where under a compantract of sale the property in the goods is transferred from the seller to the buyer, the compantract is called a sale, but where the transfer of property in the goods is to take place at a future time or subject to some companydition thereafter to be fulfilled, the compantract is called an agreement to sell.

concepts.interpretation: Distinguishes contract of sale (immediate transfer of property) from agreement to sell (future or conditional transfer); applied to hold contracts were agreements to sell becoming sales later.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: quirement of the section is number only that there shall be appropriation of the goods to the companytract but that such appropriation must be made un

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 4 Indian Sale of Goods Act
concepts.unlisted_description: Definition of contract of sale and agreement to sell based on transfer of property

anchor.surface_text: By sub-section  4  of that section an agreement to sell becomes a sale when the time elapses or the companyditions are fulfilled subject to which the property in the goods is to be transferred.

concepts.interpretation: Agreement to sell becomes sale upon fulfillment of conditions for property transfer.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: or other bailer for the purpose of transmission to the buyer, the property in the goods does number pass to the buyer until the companyditions impose

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 4(4) Indian Sale of Goods Act
concepts.unlisted_description: Conversion of agreement to sell into sale upon lapse of time or fulfillment of conditions

concepts.interpretation: No property transfer in unascertained goods until ascertained; applied as contracts were for unascertained goods.

anchor.surface_text: section 23 which lays down that where there is a compantract for the sale of unascertained or future goods by description and goods of that description and in a,, deliverable state are unconditionally appropriated to the companytract, either by the seller with the assent of the buyer or by the buyer with the assent of the seller, the property in the goods thereupon passes to the buyer.

concepts.interpretation: Property passes upon unconditional appropriation to contract; not met here due to conditions.

concepts.unlisted_description: Passing of property by unconditional appropriation of unascertained goods

anchor.surface_text: This argument, however, overlooks the important word unconditionally used in the section. The requirement of the section is number only that there shall be appropriation of the goods to the companytract but that such appropriation must be made unconditionally.

concepts.interpretation: Appropriation must be unconditional for property to pass; shipment alone insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: This is further elaborated by section 25 which provides that where there is a compantract for the sale of specific goods or where goods are subsequently appropriated to the compantract, the seller may, by the. terms. of the compantract or appropriation,, reserve the right of disposal of the goods until certain companyditions are fulfilled. In such a case, numberwithstanding the delivery of the goods to the buyer, or to a carrier or other bailer for the purpose of transmission to the buyer, the property in the goods does number pass to the buyer until the companyditions imposed by the seller are fulfilled.

concepts.interpretation: Seller can reserve right of disposal despite delivery; property does not pass until conditions fulfilled; applied via retention of bill of lading until payment.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the profits derived by the assessee company from sales made to European and American buyers arose outside British India?

arguments.claim: Sales took place in British India as property in goods passed at Madras based on FOB terms for price and delivery, insurance by buyers in European contracts, and payment of 80 or 90 percent in Madras upon delivery of documents

anchor.surface_text: Learned Solicitor-General appearing in support of this appeal contends that having regard to the terms of the contracts the sales must be regarded as having taken place in British India. The facts strongly relied on by him are that the price and delivery of goods were on F.O.B. terms,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e place, wherever that be, where, the sales took place. This was number disputed before the High Court or before us although in the appellants stateme

arguments.claim: Agreed principle that income arises at place where sales took place is erroneous

arguments.claim: Contract is sale only if property transferred immediately; here agreements to sell becoming sales later when conditions fulfilled per section 4 SOGA

anchor.surface_text: According to section 4 of the Indian Sale of Goods Act a contract of sale of goods is a contract whereby the seller transfer, or agrees to transfer the property in goods to the buyer for a price and where under a contract of sale the property in the goods is transferred from the seller to the buyer,

arguments.claim: Contracts for unascertained goods so property not transferred until goods ascertained per section 18 SOGA

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 of the Act clearly indicates that in the case of sale of unascertained goods no property in the goods is transferred to the buyer unless and until the goods are ascertained. In the present case, the contracts were always for sale of unascertained goods.

arguments.claim: Property passes on unconditional appropriation of unascertained goods to contract per section 23 SOGA; shipment does not suffice without unconditional

anchor.surface_text: section 23 which lays down that where there is a contract for the sale of unascertained or future goods by description and goods of that description and in a deliverable state are unconditionally appropriated to the contract, either by the seller with the assent of the buyer

arguments.claim: Seller reserved right of disposal until conditions fulfilled per section 25 SOGA despite delivery to carrier; retention of bill of lading until payment prevents property passing

arguments.claim: Profits received in Madras irrespective of sale place as assessee received payment of 80/90% of provisional invoice from Eastern Bank Madras upon handing documents, constituting receipt of price

anchor.surface_text: As to the second question, the learned Solicitor-General contends that irrespective of the place where the sale may have taken place the profits derived from such sales were received in Madras. It is recalled that after shipment the assessee company, through its managing agent in Madras,

arguments.court_reasoning: Eastern Banks were agents of assessee; payment was advance on security of bill of lading and drawer liability, not price payment by or on behalf of buyer

arguments.claim: Eastern Bank Madras and London were agents of assessee, not buyers; payment by own bank is advance, not receipt of sale price which occurs when buyer's bank pays in London

anchor.surface_text: In this case the fact found is that the Eastern Bank Ltd., Madras, and the Eastern Bank Ltd., London, were agents of the assessee company. Neither of them had any relation with the buyers. Therefore, a payment by them cannot be regarded as a payment of the price.

arguments.claim: Discounting bill with bank accompanied by bill of lading is advance on security, not receipt of price; bank surrenders BL against acceptance per Prinz Adalbert
Sales took place outside British India and money received by agent in London

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal by its order dated the 22nd January,1948, came to the conclusion that the sales took place outside British India and that the money in respect of such sales was also received by the agent of the assessee company in London.

arguments.court_reasoning: Upheld after detailed analysis of SOGA provisions and facts of dealing

holdings.text: the property in the goods could not have passed to the buyer earlier than the date when the bill of exchange was accepted by the buyers Bank in London and the documents were delivered by the assessee companys agent, the Eastern Bank Ltd., London, to the buyers Bank

anchor.surface_text: Suffice it to say, for the purposes of this case, that in any event upon the terms of the compantracts in question and the course of dealings between the parties the property in the goods could not have passed to the buyer earlier than the date when the bill of exchange was accepted by the buyers Bank in London and the documents were delivered by the assessee companys agent,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contracts for unascertained goods with reservation of right of disposal under sections 4, 18, 23, 25 of Sale of Goods Act; shipment and FOB terms insufficient due to retention of bill of lading until acceptance and delivery of documents in London

holdings.text: the sales took place outside British India and, ex hypothesis the profits derived from such sales arose outside British India

anchor.surface_text: It must, therefore, follow that at the earliest the property in the goods passed in London where the bill of lading was handed over to the buyers Bank against the acceptance of the relative bill of exchange. In the premises, the Appellate Tribunal as well as the High Court were quite correct in holding that the sales took place outside British India and, ex hypothesis the profits derived from such sales arose outside British India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreed that profits arise at place of sale; sale where property passes, which was in London

holdings.text: the Eastern Bank Ltd., Madras, and the Eastern Bank Ltd., London., were agents of the assessee company. Neither of them had any relation with the buyers. Therefore, a payment by them cannot be regarded as a payment of the price

anchor.surface_text: In this case the fact found is that the Eastern Bank Ltd., Madras, and the Eastern Bank Ltd., London., were agents of the assessee company. Neither of them had any relation with the buyers. Therefore, a payment by them cannot be regarded as a payment of the price.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Banks acted as assessee's agents, no relation to buyers; payment by own agents not receipt from buyer

holdings.text: This payment by the Eastern Bank Ltd., Madras, therefore, is nothing but an advance made by them to their own customer on the security of the goods covered by the bill of lading reinforced by the benefit of the liability taken up by the assessee company as drawer of the bill
holdings.reasoning_summary: Discounting unaccepted bill with bill of lading is advance on security, per precedent in Prinz Adalbert; seller remains liable as drawer

holdings.text: the price was paid on behalf of the buyers by their respective London Banks in London to the Eastern Bank Ltd., London which was the agent of the assessee company. The first receipt of the price, therefore [...] was by the Eastern Bank Ltd., London, on behalf of the sellers
holdings.reasoning_summary: Actual payment by buyers' banks to seller's agent in London constitutes first receipt of price there; balance also received there

holdings.text: the High Court correctly answered the second question also in favour of the assessee company
holdings.reasoning_summary: Overall conclusion affirming that profits were received outside British India

anchor.surface_text: The true position is very clearly put by Lord Sumner in The Prinz Adalbert 1  When a shipper takes his draft, number as yet accepted, but accompanied by a bill of lading, indorsed in this way, and discounts it with a banker, he makes himself liable on the instrument as drawer, and he further makes the goods, which the bill of lading L.R. 1917 A.C. 586, 589.

precedents.cited_proposition: When a shipper takes his draft, number as yet accepted, but accompanied by a bill of lading, indorsed in this way, and discounts it with a banker, he makes himself liable on the instrument as drawer, and he further makes the goods, which the bill of lading represents, security for its payment.
precedents.cited_holding: When a shipper takes his draft, number as yet accepted, but accompanied by a bill of lading, indorsed in this way, and discounts it with a banker, he makes himself liable on the instrument as drawer, and he further makes the goods, which the bill of lading represents, security for its payment.
